At one time the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the country of ÅšrÄvastÄ«, together with a great assembly of 1,250 bhiká¹£us and 8,000 bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas. MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« and the celestial prince SÄrthavÄha were together in the assembly.

World-Honored One!
By how many kinds of spiritual transformations do the TathÄgatas always tame sentient beings?
The Buddha told the celestial prince:
I tame sentient beings by means of three kinds of spiritual transformations:
First, teaching the Dharma; second, admonishing; third, spiritual powers.
What is called the spiritual transformation of teaching the Dharma?

It means the TathÄgata's unobstructed great wisdom, which sees the differences in the mental activities of all sentient beings in the future world, whether they have faith or lack faith in the Three Jewels, and fully understands their karmic consequences.
As the Buddha has said, if one performs evil causes in the present world, one will fall into evil destinies, and the retribution for one's actions will be definite and without error.

If those sentient beings, due to the power of their good karmic causes and vows, are reborn among humans and gods from evil destinies, or attain liberation through the ÅšrÄvaka Vehicle, Pratyekabuddha Vehicle, or Great Vehicle, and experience suffering and happiness for so many kalpas before attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, or encounter so many buddhas, such karmic actions are definite and without error.

If those sentient beings, due to the power of their good karmic causes and vows, will be born in the desire realm, form realm, or formless realm, experience the vehicles for so many kalpas and attain liberation, and through such practices will get to see the Buddha and serve and make offerings to him,
all such good and evil karmic actions, even down to a single thought, the TathÄgata knows them all and preaches the Dharma for them. This is called the spiritual power of preaching the Dharma.
What is meant by the spiritual power of instruction?

If one teaches those who uphold precepts in this way, saying what should be done and what should not be done, what should be believed and what should not be believed, what should be closely attended to and what should not be closely attended to, which dharmas are defiled and which dharmas are pure, and so forth, accepting all the provisions for the path of merit and virtue, practicing this path to attain the vehicle of the Å›rÄvakas, the vehicle of the pratyekabuddhas, and practicing this path to accomplish the Great Vehicle, abandoning what is not the Dharma and abiding in what is the Dharma, as taught by the Buddha, without doubt or error.

This is the karma of hell, this is the karma of animals, this is the karma of hungry ghosts, this is the karma of humans and gods, unwholesomeness should be abandoned, wholesome dharmas should be cultivated, this is the noble path that should be studied in this way.
These beings, humans and gods going back and forth, gradually enter nirvÄá¹‡a. Such teaching and instruction will never be in vain. This is called the spiritual power of instruction.
What is called the spiritual power of spiritual penetrations?

If it is for the sake of subduing arrogant beings, they may manifest one body as many bodies, or manifest many bodies as one body, entering and exiting mountains, cliffs, and walls without obstruction, fire coming out from the upper body and water from the lower body, water coming out from the upper body and fire from the lower body, entering the earth as if it were water and walking on water as if on earth, touching the sun and moon with their hands, or manifesting a large body reaching the Brahma world and even widely covering the trichiliocosm.
Manifesting according to what is appropriate to subdue beings, this is called spiritual powers and spiritual transformations.
At that time, the Heavenly Son Merchant-Leader addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Are there any spiritual transformations that surpass this?
The Buddha told the Heavenly Son:
The TathÄgata also has a supreme spiritual transformation.
He then said to MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«:

You can expound it to enable the bodhisattvas to attain the profound acceptance of the Dharma and subdue the mÄras, and also to cause the TathÄgata's enlightenment to abide in the world for a long time.
MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

If the TathÄgata were to place the four great oceans of the trichiliocosm in the palm of his hand, and the beings in the water would not be disturbed, such a spiritual transformation would not be considered most extraordinary.

If the TathÄgata were to explain with words and phrases all dharmas that cannot be spoken of, which are without names, characteristics, forms, sounds, activities, creations, letters, disputes, representations, apart from mind, thought, and cognition, with the cessation of all paths of speech and illumination of quiescence,
which all worlds cannot understand, and upon hearing which Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as would be frightened, this would be called the greatest spiritual transformation of the buddhas.

Furthermore, if the TathÄgata were to place the trichiliocosm in his mouth, without obstructing the four continents, and the light of the sun and moon would not be obscured but remain as before, and the beings therein would not be aware of coming and going in their places,
BhagavÄn!
Such spiritual transformations are not yet the most supreme.

If the TathÄgata were to expound and reveal with words and language the inexpressible, the absence of letters, the absence of names and characteristics, up to the abandonment of mind, thought, and cognition, the cessation of all paths of speech and the illumination of quiescence, regarding all dharmas, this would be called the greatest spiritual transformation of all buddhas.
Furthermore, by the power of the spiritual penetrations of the TathÄgata's unique body, he manifests in various ways according to the various beings, causing them all to rejoice.
Such spiritual transformations are not yet the most supreme.

The so-called great supernatural power of the TathÄgata is to speak of self when there is no self, to speak of sentient beings when there are no sentient beings, to speak of person when there is no person, to speak of nurturance when there is no nurturance, to speak of name when there is no name, to speak of form when there is no form, to speak of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness when there is no feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, to speak of sense bases when there are no sense bases, to speak of elements when there are no elements. Although speaking of the emptiness of the eye, the eye does not say it is empty; although speaking of the emptiness of form, form does not say it is empty; speaking of the emptiness of eye-consciousness, consciousness does not say it is empty. Up to the emptiness of the mind, dharmas, and mind-consciousness are also like this.
Speaking of such nameless, formless, unmoving, unknowing, and inexpressible dharmas, destroying all the characteristics of arising and ceasing, this is the TathÄgata's greatest supernatural power.

Such a spiritual transformation is not associated with the eye, not associated with form, not associated with eye consciousness, not associated with the ear, sound, ear consciousness, nose, smell, nose consciousness, tongue, taste, tongue consciousness, body, touch, body consciousness, or mind, dharmas, or mind consciousness.
Such a spiritual transformation is not united with the body, not united with the mind, without activity, without fabrication, free from all objects, and cannot be believed by all worldly beings.
Why is this?
What is called the world is called the five aggregates.
Ordinary beings falsely give rise to attachment to this, saying that the aggregates are either permanent or impermanent.
For this reason, all worldly beings falsely see the aggregates as permanent, and when they hear that they are impermanent, they are unable to give rise to faith;
they falsely see the aggregates as blissful, and when they hear that the aggregates are suffering, they are unable to give rise to faith;
they falsely see the aggregates as having a self, and when they hear that they are without a self, they are unable to give rise to faith;
they falsely see the aggregates as pure, and when they hear that they are impure, they are unable to give rise to faith;
Counting the aggregates as one's own, saying there is no one's own cannot give rise to faith;
Counting the five aggregates as real, hearing that they are unreal cannot give rise to faith.
For this reason, the TathÄgata's spiritual transformations surpass the characteristics of the mind. Those who hear it are not delighted, and all worlds cannot believe it.
Furthermore, surpassing the realm of the eyes, because it is not a form, this is called a spiritual transformation.

Surpassing the realm of the ears, because it is not a sound, and so forth, up to surpassing the realm of the mind, because it is not a mental object, it cannot be revealed and is not known by cognition, this is called a spiritual transformation.
Furthermore, emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness cannot be spoken of, yet speaking of emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, this is called a spiritual transformation.
Non-arising, non-action, naturelessness, signlessness, non-birth, non-cessation, and original nirvÄá¹‡a cannot be spoken of, yet speaking of nirvÄá¹‡a, this is called a spiritual transformation.
Furthermore, generosity is pure because it purifies the three spheres, this is called a spiritual transformation.
What are the three?
It means being free from the notion of self and the notion of sentient beings, not thinking of enlightenment, and upholding pure precepts. This is called a spiritual transformation.

It means that the actions of body, speech, and mind are without activity, and therefore patience is pure. This is called a spiritual transformation.ğŸ”½Because it is instantly destroyed and without attachment, diligence is pure. This is called a spiritual transformation.
Because there is no coming or going, and the body and mind are unmoving, meditative concentration is pure. This is called a spiritual transformation.
Because the mind is without support and the inner and outer are tranquil, wisdom is pure. This is called a spiritual transformation.
It is because it illuminates all dharmas and extinguishes all views.
Furthermore, to speak of the Dharma of liberation using the mark of non-emergence of the Dharma is called a spiritual transformation.

To distinguish the Dharma using written characters, although the Dharma is without distinctions, is called a spiritual transformation.ğŸ”½To speak of practice while the Dharma is without activity is called a spiritual transformation.
To speak of coming and going while the Dharma is without coming or going is called a spiritual transformation.
To establish the various fruits while realizing the one path is called a spiritual transformation.
To distinguish three vehicles within the one-flavored Dharma is called a spiritual transformation.
All buddhas are only one buddha, yet to speak of innumerable buddhas is called a spiritual transformation.
All buddha lands are only one buddha land, yet to speak of innumerable lands is called a spiritual transformation.

Immeasurable sentient beings are actually one sentient being, yet to speak of immeasurable sentient beings is called a spiritual transformation.ğŸ”½All buddha-dharmas are only one buddha-dharma, yet to speak of innumerable dharmas is called a spiritual transformation.
The Dharma cannot be shown, yet to reveal all dharmas is called a spiritual transformation.

At that time, the god-son Merchant Leader said to MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«,

When this Dharma was being spoken, twelve thousand devas generated the intention to achieve unsurpassable and perfect enlightenment, and five hundred bodhisattvas attained the forbearance of the birthlessness of dharmas.

In the distant past, beyond countless eons, there was a buddha named Sumeru TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One, who appeared in the world.

ÅšÄriputra!
All sentient beings in that buddha-land are endowed with happiness, and there is not even the sound of suffering.

That buddha-land is made of four treasures: gold, silver, lapis lazuli, and crystal. The ground is flat like the palm of a hand, pure and soft like heavenly fine garments, without any difficult places.
Filled with devas and humans, peaceful and prosperous, with immeasurable happiness and joy, it is therefore called the Land of Bliss.

In that buddha's Dharma, there are only bodhisattvas, who are diligent, courageous, and wise, have attained the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« of the king of sÅ«tras, have inexhaustible eloquence and skillful means, skillfully distinguish and expound the Dharma with spiritual powers and wisdom, defeat evil mÄras, are liberated without obstruction, accomplish the forbearance of samÄdhi, well understand the nature of faculties and prescribe medicine according to the illness, possess the provisions of great merit and wisdom, and are unasked friends for all sentient beings.

With the power of spiritual penetrations, they traveled to buddha-lands everywhere, entered the ocean of wisdom and practice, and peacefully abided in giving, precepts, wisdom, and much learning. That Buddha-World-Honored One had such great bodhisattvas as his retinue.

The king had a thousand sons, all of whom had given rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

The king, together with his thousand sons and his harem, attained pure faith, loved the Dharma, rejoiced, and had no other thoughts. They always personally made offerings to the Buddha in front of him, closely listened to the Dharma for over a hundred thousand years.
At that time, the king's thousand sons and the inner palace attained the four mindfulnesses.
What are the four?
First, mindfulness of the Buddha and bodhisattvas; second, mindfulness of giving; third, mindfulness of precepts; fourth, not forgetting the mind of enlightenment.
Having attained this mindfulness, they always got to see the Buddha and bodhisattvas day and night.
Later, at one time, King Pure Adornments and his retinue went to where the Buddha was in order to listen to the Dharma.

Great King!

'The Tathagata has another supreme spiritual power, namely, he knows the past has ceased, the present does not abide, and the future has not yet arisen, yet without mind or mental factors he speaks of the dharmas of mind and mental factors in the three times. In the one flavor he speaks of the three liberations, in the realization of one cessation he speaks of the four noble truths, he reveals the emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness of all dharmas, he matures sentient beings who are upside-down and suffering, he speaks of signlessness and non-action to accomplish enlightenment.

In not grasping or abandoning, they speak of the perfection of giving; in abiding in nothing and acting in nothing, they speak of the perfection of morality; in the Dharma of no-self, they speak of the perfection of patience; in the tranquility of body and mind, they speak of the perfection of vigor; in neither distraction nor concentration, they speak of the perfection of meditation; in transcending this shore and the other shore, they speak of the perfection of wisdom. They practice skillful means with no thought of movement, cultivate kindness free from the characteristics of reliance, cultivate compassion with unconditioned dharmas, cultivate joy free from delight, and cultivate equanimity with the Dharma of non-abiding.

With nothing to see, they give rise to the heavenly eye; with nothing to hear, they give rise to the heavenly ear; with no object of perception, they give rise to the knowledge of others' minds; free from the past, they give rise to the knowledge of past lives; with unmoving body and mind, they give rise to the supernormal powers.

They do not abide in the Dharma but cultivate mindfulness, cultivate the four right efforts without birth or cessation, speak of faculties where there are none, speak of powers where there are none, speak of the factors of enlightenment as the quiescence of all dharmas, cultivate the eightfold path without discrimination, cultivate Å›amatha without abiding in quiescence, cultivate vipaÅ›yanÄ by being apart from the characteristics of dharmas, and speak of nirvÄá¹‡a as originally quiescent.

When that Buddha-BhagavÄn spoke this dhÄraá¹‡Ä«-seal-sÅ«tra for the sake of King Pure Adornment's thousand sons and their retinue, eighty-four thousand sentient beings gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
King Pure Adornment and his thousand sons attained acceptance of the Dharma. By the Buddha's spiritual power, they praised in verse before the Buddha:
Like Mount Sumeru reflecting in the great ocean, the TathÄgata's majestic light
obscures the great assembly.

but is unstained and unattached.
Like the lion king roaring in the forest, the human lion roars in the nature of emptiness.
Explaining that all dharmas are neither existent nor nonexistent, causing one to depart from extreme views, is called the lion's roar.
Regarding all characteristics, whether arising or ceasing, explaining that there is neither arising nor ceasing,
is called the lion's roar.
Distinguishing this shore or demonstrating the other shore, not dwelling in any dharmas, is called the lion's roar.
Distinguishing the two characteristics, being defiled or pure, the nature of all dharmas is pure, is called the lion's roar.
The activities of greed, anger, and delusion arise from discrimination. Not giving rise to discrimination,
Is called the lion's roar.
Explaining that the dharmas of birth and death are impermanent and without self, arising from delusion, is called the lion's roar.
Birth and death and nirvÄá¹‡a are originally quiescent, this is great enlightenment, called the lion's roar.
Those bound by various views, transmigrating in the world, revealing emptiness of intrinsic nature,
Is called the lion's roar.
The spiritual transformations manifested by the TathÄgata, the guide, are all able to reveal them, called the lion's roar.
In all that is contrary or agreeable, the mind is unmoved,
Always abiding in equality, called the acceptance of the Dharma in accordance with the teachings.
In accordance with the profound and tranquil Dharma spoken by the Buddha,
Also not realizing it therein, called the acceptance of the Dharma in accordance with the teachings.
Far from all faults and evils, increasing in wholesome dharmas,
Not attached to them, called the acceptance of the Dharma in accordance with the teachings.
The sound of speaking of the emptiness of all phenomena, and the sound of all views,
Not attached to either, is called the acceptance of following the Dharma.
The sound of boundless Buddha-dharmas, and the sound of various afflictions,
Not giving rise to discrimination of sounds, is called the acceptance of following the Dharma.
In giving, morality, much learning, diligence, concentration, and wisdom,
Practicing in accordance with the Dharma, is called the acceptance of following the Dharma.
Not abandoning the mind of enlightenment, and equally observing all,
The pure path to enlightenment, is called the acceptance of following the Dharma.
The Tathagata's own words reveal the Buddha-dharmas,
Having no doubts about this, is called the acceptance of following the Dharma.
If I attain enlightenment, I will roar the lion's roar,
Expounding this spiritual transformation as the Buddha now speaks.
In the inconceivable, supreme great field of merit,
Having already planted the seeds, there will be no turning back.
Even if the great earth is destroyed and the great ocean dries up,
The wholesome roots I have planted will never be lost.
Understanding that the nature of sentient beings' minds is like empty space,
Deeply planting the seeds of enlightenment, one attains boundless blessings and virtues.
As for my aspirations now, only the Buddha can fully understand,
The gods, humans, and gandharvas have no one who can know them.
I now do not seek the supreme and wonderful rewards of the gods,
I shall attain wisdom, just like the Buddha, the Honored One among humans.
For hundreds of thousands of years, I will closely attend and make offerings to the Buddha,
In order to set out for enlightenment, I will cultivate this boundless karma.
I now, together with my thousand sons, and the inner palace and retinue,
Wish to always make offerings to the Buddha, in order to mature enlightenment.
I have now obtained great benefits, and well seen the buddhas,
And well heard this Dharma, loving and delighting in bodhi.
If one loves and delights in bodhi, then one loves and delights in the Dharma,
Out of compassion for sentient beings, not abandoning the Buddha's vehicle.'
At that time, among the assembly there was a bodhisattva named Dharma Speed, who said to King Pure Adornment:
'Great King!
You do not accord with the TathÄgata's spiritual powers, and you are also not heading towards unsurpassed bodhi.
Why is this?
Great King!

Bodhi abides in the Dharma realm, neither coming nor going, without knowledge or action, neither form nor characteristics, neither grasping nor abandoning, like painting in empty space without obstruction, originally pure by nature.
Great King!ğŸ”½Bodhi enters everywhere, because all dharmas are equal.ğŸ”½Bodhi is without discrimination, because it is free from characteristics.
Bodhi is tranquil, because it is the characteristic of cessation.
The nature of enlightenment is pure, because it is free from attachment.
Enlightenment is unmoving, because it is free from confusion.
Great King!
Enlightenment is called the equality of the mind, because it does not arise.
Enlightenment is called the equality of sentient beings, because they are originally unborn.
Enlightenment is called the unborn arising, because causes and conditions have no nature.
Enlightenment cannot be revealed, because it is free from mind, thought, and cognition.
Great King!
Enlightenment has no activity, because it transcends all objects.
Enlightenment is free from conceptual proliferation, because it is free from the characteristics of discursive thought.
Enlightenment is emptiness, because its nature and characteristics are empty.
Enlightenment is signless, because it is free from all signs.
Enlightenment is wishless, because it has no abode.
Enlightenment is non-action, because it has no karmic retribution.
Enlightenment is unconditioned, because it is free from the three characteristics.
Great King!
The nature and characteristics of enlightenment are like this.
If one has any wishes or pursuits regarding this Dharma, it is merely exhausting oneself in vain.
Why is it so?
As the nature of enlightenment, bodhisattvas should practice. Being able to practice like this is called right practice.'
At that time King Pure Adornment said to Bodhisattva Swift Dharma:
'Please explain to me the correct practice of bodhisattvas.'
Swift Dharma said:
'Great King!
Abandoning all possessions is the practice of bodhisattvas, because all sentient beings are equal and without discrimination.
Practicing the dhÅ«ta precepts is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the nature of precepts is equal and without practice.
Being free from anger and distress is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the nature of patience is equal and without mental characteristics.
Being firm and courageous is the practice of bodhisattvas, because diligence is equal and free from mental activity.
SamÄdhi and liberation are the practice of bodhisattvas, because meditative concentration is equal and without objects.
The accumulation of learning and wisdom is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the nature of wisdom is equal and without thought.
Being born in the abode of BrahmÄ is the practice of bodhisattvas, because defilement and purity are equal, both being abandoned.'
Giving rise to various spiritual powers is the practice of bodhisattvas, because spiritual powers are equal and one does not give rise to thoughts.
Being fully endowed with eloquence is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the equality of dharmas and meanings is free from the characteristics of the mind.
Achieving supreme understanding is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the dharma realm is equal and unmoving.
Cultivating the seven factors of enlightenment is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the equality of contemplation is free from laziness.
Giving rise to the four means of conversion is the practice of bodhisattvas, because all dharmas are equal and the same as their activities.
Treating sentient beings equally is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the nature of the mind is equal and free from discrimination.
Adorning the Buddha's land is the practice of bodhisattvas, because purity is equal and like space.
The thirty-two marks are the practice of bodhisattvas, because contemplating the dharma without characteristics enters into equality.
Purifying body, speech, and mind is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the nature of the three karmas is equal and free.
Rejoicing in sentient beings is the practice of bodhisattvas, because all sentient beings are equal and without self.
Not being weary of birth and death is the practice of bodhisattvas, because they understand that it is of the same nature as a dream.
Constantly cultivating wholesome actions is the practice of bodhisattvas, because they know that actions are of the same nature and that there is no retribution for actions.
Firmly practicing is the practice of bodhisattvas, because they observe that all dharmas are like magical transformations.
Patiently enduring various sufferings is the practice of bodhisattvas, because they understand that suffering is of the same nature and does not arise.
Being close to good friends is the practice of bodhisattvas, because their minds are impartial towards friends and non-friends.
Diligent cultivation of the profound mind is the practice of bodhisattvas, because they seek no rewards and are of the same nature.
Not being weary of much learning is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the one who expounds the Dharma and the one who listens to the Dharma are of the same nature.
Not being stingy with the Dharma is the practice of bodhisattvas, because they expound the Dharma impartially without seeking anything in return.
Embracing the true Dharma is the practice of bodhisattvas, because they mature the Buddhadharmas impartially.
Always seeking true wisdom is the practice of bodhisattvas, because the nature of the ultimate truth is of the same nature.
The practice of a bodhisattva is to humble one's mind, because one humbles oneself equally towards all sentient beings.
The practice of a bodhisattva is to universally gather all wholesome merits and virtues, because one is impartial towards merits and has no thoughts.

At that time, King Pure Adornment, having heard of such bodhisattva practices, was overjoyed and gave rise to a mind of love and appreciation. He immediately took off his clothes and ornaments and gave them to Bodhisattva Swift Dharma.
At that time, the king's thousand sons also each took off their ornaments and offered them to the bodhisattvas, saying:
May all sentient beings accomplish the practices of bodhisattvas and attain such eloquence.
We have now obtained great benefits and have been able to see such true and good spiritual friends and make offerings to them with respect.
At that time, Bodhisattva Swift Dharma said to King Pure Adornment:
The offerings you have made are very inferior. You should know that there are also superior offerings.
At that time, Bodhisattva Swift Dharma spoke in verse, saying:
The beings in the trichiliocosm all give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment,
Even if they were to make offerings of sons and daughters for an entire eon,
If a person gives rise to the intention for the Way and goes forth with faith,
Following the Buddha to cultivate and study, their merit surpasses that.
In the past and future worlds, all the TathÄgatas,
There is none who has not left the household life and attained the unsurpassed Way.
The Buddhas of the three times praise the Dharma of leaving the household life,
If one delights in making offerings to the Buddha, one should leave the household life in accordance with the Buddha.
Even if one fills worlds as numerous as the sands of the Ganges with precious treasures to make offerings to the Buddha,
It is not as good as leaving the household life and cultivating tranquility for a single day.
Then one is close to enlightenment, destroying the armies of MÄra,
Leaving the household life and not being negligent, the wholesome dharmas always increase.
Not destroying the wholesome roots, far removing the afflictions,
Abandoning the burdens of family affairs, in accord with the path, praised by the sages.
Abandoning the family, free from the bonds of afflictions, removing afflictions, free from the bonds of Mara,
The mind liberated, practicing without defilement, will soon realize enlightenment.'
